Yesterday I attended an Inland Northwest ACM meeting in downtown Spokane.  The topic was one I am familiar with but never actually put into practice: Extreme Programming.  Probably one of the best sites on this topic is www.xprogramming.com and I was pleased to see there is quite a bit of C# stuff there in addition to the expected JAVA. 

Below are some notes from the talk... real basic but that is what I wrote anyway:

  • pair programming - all production code is written by two developers at one screen, if asked to pair you have to say yes although you may negotiate for something….  Pair programming decreases truck factor (the consequences if someone gets hit by a truck.

  • Use numbering system of 1-3 for each story and give the customer a total that they can have as many stories add up to.

  • Daily standup meetings

Questions:

  1. What is the measure that you have got enough code covereage for a unit test?  Almost one hundred percent.  You write one test then write the code to get the test to pass.  Then you write the next test.

  2. How do you compile test without at least first defining the interfaces for your implementation?  Use code by intention.  At first your tests don't compile.  You don't write the complete test and then all the code, however.  See answer above.

  3. How do you handle usability?  Easily, you let the customer use what you build as you go and get their immediate feedback.

Some notes about testing
  • When you find a bug write a test to demonstrate the bug then fix it.  This stems from the idea that if your tests are good you wouldn't have any bugs so fix your tests.
